citation.article-title: Molecular identification of rRNA group 3 bacilli (Ash, Farrow, Wallbanks and Collins) using a PCR probe test. Proposal for the creation of a new genus Paenibacillus.

p.s: Paenibacillus (pae. ba. cillus., L. adv. paene, almost; bacterial name, bacillus; N.L. mas. n; Paenibacillus almost a bacillus, because it derives from this genus but is phylogenetically distinct.)
The description is based upon data taken from several sources (Claus & Berkeley 1986).
Cells are rods of Gram-positive structure but usually stain negatively in the laboratory Gram stain.
Cells are non-pigmented and motile by means of peritrichous flagella.
They differentiate into ellipsoidal endospores that distinctively swell the sporangium.
Acid and sometimes gas are produced from various sugars including glucose and with odd exceptions cellobiose, galactose, raffinose and salicin.
Acid is not produced from adonitol and sorbitol.
Urease-negative (with exception of B. validus) and arginine dihydrolase negative.
Citrate is not utilized and no growth occurs in the presence of 10% sodium chloride.
Macromolecules are commonly degraded by extracellular enzymes including carboxymethylcellulose, DNA, protein and starch but not all species hydrolyse all of these substrates.
The diamino acid in the peptidoglycan is meso-diaminopimelic acid and the major isoprenoid quinone is an unsaturated menaquinone with seven isoprene units.
The long-chain cellular fatly acids are primarily of the straight-chain saturated, anteiso and iso-branched types with anteiso-C15 predominating.
The G+C content of the DNA is 40-54 mole %.Isolated largely from decomposing plant materials and humus-enriched soils.
The type species is P. polymyxa (oldest member of the group).
